news_summary: Several countries are actively attracting PhD students by offering promising opportunities amid uncertainties in US research funding.
news_summary_fr: Plusieurs pays attirent activement les doctorants en leur offrant des opportunités prometteuses dans un contexte d'incertitude quant au financement de la recherche aux États-Unis.
news_summary_es: Varios países están atrayendo activamente a estudiantes de doctorado ofreciéndoles oportunidades prometedoras en medio de la incertidumbre sobre la financiación de la investigación en Estados Unidos.

articles.title: These nations are wooing PhD students amid US funding uncertainties
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 09 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02416-xPauses to some US graduate programmes have led universities in several countries to launch initiatives to entice would-be PhD students.
articles.content:
The United States has long been one of the most popular destinations for international students pursuing graduate studies. But pauses to some of the country’s university PhD programmes and the imposition of visa restrictions for students from certain countries have prompted other nations to try to attract those students who have been affected by the changes or who no longer want to study in the United States.

US President Donald Trump’s administration has proposed slashing budgets at some of the country’s top scientific agencies and has frozen funds for grants and contracts for universities.

Chris Tisdell, a researcher in education and mathematics at the University of New South Wales (UNSW) in Sydney, Australia, says he has heard reports of international students already shifting away from the United States because of uncertainties surrounding funding. International student arrivals dropped by 30% in June this year compared with June 2024, according to data reported by the US International Trade Administration.

Gwilym Croucher, a researcher in higher education at the University of Melbourne, Australia, says he expects talented PhD candidates to look elsewhere. “The beneficiaries of that may be established places like Canada, Australia, the UK, a lot of Europe, but they may also be China and India,” he says.

So, which countries have stepped up efforts to woo PhD students? And what are they offering?

Canada

Several universities in Canada have set up programmes to attract students from the United States.

In July, Western University in London launched a Doctoral Excellence Award, targeting current and prospective students of US universities, including those who have had an offer rescinded in the past six months, at US universities ranked in the top 100 globally. Initially, 25 students will be supported, receiving a PhD stipend for up to four years of study, as well as “fast-tracked admissions and help finding a supervisor”, says Florentine Strzelczyk, Western University’s provost. PhD stipends increased across Canada, after the government set a blanket rate of Can$40,000 annually last year.

Earlier this year, the University of British Columbia in Vancouver also extended the deadline to allow for late applications from US citizens to be considered for certain graduate programmes starting in January 2026.

Alicia Piazza is in her third year of a PhD at Brock University in St. Catharine’s and recommends Canada for graduate studies, particularly because of the quality of training on offer. “I’m three years in and I’m still learning,” she says. The classes she has attended, including one on grant writing and another on presenting and analysing research papers, have prepared her to work in academia or industry. Students at the university are also encouraged to apply for external funding, and she successfully applied for a scholarship from the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada.

Piazza receives a stipend from the university that covers her tuition fees, and was also guaranteed a position as a teaching assistant, which helps to cover living expenses, she says. “The rent is not too bad, so it’s pretty affordable,” she adds.

Europe

France, Germany and Spain are among other countries that have introduced new programmes to attract students, particularly those from the United States, alongside initiatives to attract scientists further on in their careers.

The University of Paris-Saclay in Orsay, France, is offering eight spots for students to pursue a PhD in subjects spanning climate and environmental science, global health, humanities, social sciences and energy transition. Students who have already started a PhD in the United States are also eligible. International students can apply for several scholarships that cover accommodation and living costs, and in some cases health insurance. Students supported by funding from their university, institution or the national research agency receive between €16,800 (US$19,400) and €18,000 per year.

Meanwhile, the Max Planck Society in Germany has launched a Transatlantic Program and encouraged prospective students to apply to programmes at its international research schools and graduate centres. Doctoral students are under contract with the society, with set working hours of 39 hours per week and a minimum pay of €32,400 per year.
articles.reasoning: The article describes how several countries are proactively creating programs and funding opportunities to attract PhD students affected by funding cuts and visa restrictions in the US. This represents a positive, tangible shift in global higher education access and opportunities for international students, benefiting a broad population of aspiring researchers.
articles.personality_title: Canada and Europe launch new programs to attract PhD students amid US funding cuts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United States has long been a top choice for international students seeking PhD degrees. Recently, some US universities paused their graduate programs and introduced visa restrictions, creating uncertainty for many students.

**What happened** – In response, countries like Canada, France, Germany, and Spain have started new initiatives to welcome PhD students affected by these US changes. For example, Western University in Canada offers a Doctoral Excellence Award with financial support and fast admissions for students from US universities. European institutions such as the University of Paris-Saclay and the Max Planck Society provide scholarships and paid contracts to attract international doctoral candidates.

**Impact** – These programs give students more options to continue their studies without interruption. They also show how countries can work to keep research alive by supporting talented students when others face funding or visa problems. For students, this means access to quality education, financial help, and opportunities to prepare for careers in science and academia.

**What's next step** – As these programs grow, more students might choose to study outside the US. Universities in these countries may expand their support and create partnerships to welcome even more international researchers in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New scholarships and programs in Canada and Europe are opening doors for PhD students affected by US funding and visa challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Canada et l'Europe lancent des programmes pour attirer les doctorants face aux coupes budgétaires aux États-Unis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les États-Unis ont longtemps été une destination privilégiée pour les étudiants internationaux en doctorat. Récemment, certains programmes de doctorat américains ont été suspendus et des restrictions de visa ont été mises en place, créant de l'incertitude pour de nombreux étudiants.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En réponse, des pays comme le Canada, la France, l'Allemagne et l'Espagne ont lancé de nouvelles initiatives pour accueillir les doctorants affectés par ces changements américains. Par exemple, l'Université Western au Canada propose une Bourse d'Excellence Doctorale avec un soutien financier et une admission accélérée pour les étudiants venant d'universités américaines. Des institutions européennes comme l'Université Paris-Saclay et la Société Max Planck offrent des bourses et des contrats rémunérés pour attirer les doctorants internationaux.

**Impact** – Ces programmes offrent aux étudiants plus d'options pour poursuivre leurs études sans interruption. Ils montrent aussi comment les pays peuvent soutenir la recherche en aidant les étudiants talentueux face aux problèmes de financement ou de visa. Pour les étudiants, cela signifie un accès à une éducation de qualité, une aide financière et des opportunités pour préparer leur carrière scientifique.

**Prochaine étape** – Avec le développement de ces programmes, davantage d'étudiants pourraient choisir d'étudier hors des États-Unis. Les universités pourraient renforcer leur soutien et créer des partenariats pour accueillir encore plus de chercheurs internationaux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles bourses et programmes au Canada et en Europe ouvrent des opportunités aux doctorants touchés par les difficultés de financement et de visa aux États-Unis.
articles.personality_title_es: Canadá y Europa lanzan programas para atraer a estudiantes de doctorado ante recortes de fondos en EE.UU.
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Estados Unidos ha sido durante mucho tiempo un destino preferido para estudiantes internacionales que buscan un doctorado. Recientemente, algunas universidades estadounidenses pausaron sus programas de posgrado y establecieron restricciones de visa, generando incertidumbre para muchos estudiantes.

**Qué pasó** – En respuesta, países como Canadá, Francia, Alemania y España han iniciado nuevas iniciativas para atraer a estudiantes de doctorado afectados por estos cambios en EE.UU. Por ejemplo, la Western University en Canadá ofrece un Premio a la Excelencia Doctoral con apoyo financiero y admisión rápida para estudiantes de universidades estadounidenses. Instituciones europeas como la Universidad de Paris-Saclay y la Sociedad Max Planck ofrecen becas y contratos pagados para atraer a candidatos internacionales.

**Impacto** – Estos programas brindan a los estudiantes más opciones para continuar sus estudios sin interrupciones. También muestran cómo los países pueden apoyar la investigación al ayudar a estudiantes talentosos frente a problemas de financiamiento o visa. Para los estudiantes, significa acceso a educación de calidad, ayuda económica y oportunidades para prepararse para carreras científicas.

**Próximo paso** – A medida que crezcan estos programas, más estudiantes podrían elegir estudiar fuera de EE.UU. Las universidades podrían ampliar su apoyo y crear asociaciones para recibir a más investigadores internacionales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevas becas y programas en Canadá y Europa están abriendo puertas para estudiantes de doctorado afectados por los desafíos de financiamiento y visa en EE.UU.
